title: Place-keeping: capturing and developing the capacity of cross-sector partnerships to deliver successful green spaces
abstractText:
Despite funding being available for ‘place-making’ ie the implementation/ creation of open spaces, the long term management - or ‘place-keeping’ - of these spaces is often neglected and initial benefits may be lost over time. In addition, the economic recession has led to severe budget cuts to green space management as it is a non-statutory service.

This project aims to examine the extent to which cross-sector partnerships are effective in managing green spaces.There is a long history of public, private, third sector organisations and community stakeholders getting involved in managing and maintaining green spaces. However, we do not know how well cross-sector partnerships deliver good green space management.

To address this gap in knowledge, this project aims to develop and apply their partnership capacity approach as a method of place-keeping evaluation in the city of Sheffield.

Working closely with project partners (Sheffield City Council, Green Estate, Sheffield Wildlife Trust and Tinder Foundation), the project team will conduct interviews, workshops and hold a large-scale event. The project website will be a key dissemination tool with blogs and ongoing discussions at the forthcoming  www.place-keeping.org.
